module.title: Time Value of Money Fundamentals
module.description: Master the core concept that money available today is worth more than the same amount in the future
learningObjectives: Understand the fundamental principle of time value of money
Calculate present value and future value of cash flows
Use financial calculators and formulas effectively

sections.title: Why Time Value of Money Matters

content.text: The time value of money (TVM) is arguably the most important concept in finance. It states that money available at the present time is worth more than the identical sum in the future due to its potential earning capacity.
keyPoints: A dollar today is worth more than a dollar tomorrow
Money can earn returns when invested
Inflation erodes purchasing power over time

realWorldExample.description: In 2007, Netflix offered to sell itself to Blockbuster for $50 million. Blockbuster declined. By understanding TVM, we can evaluate this decision. That $50 million invested at 10% annual return would be worth about $270 million by 2023. Netflix's actual value in 2023? Over $150 billion. The time value principle shows us both the opportunity cost of Blockbuster's decision and Netflix's incredible value creation.

sections.title: Present Value: Bringing Future Money to Today

content.text: Present Value (PV) tells us what future money is worth in today's dollars. It's the foundation of all valuation in finance.

step_by_step.title: Identify the Future Value
step_by_step.description: Determine the amount you will receive in the future

step_by_step.title: Determine the Discount Rate
step_by_step.description: Find the appropriate interest rate or required return

step_by_step.title: Count the Periods
step_by_step.description: Calculate the number of compounding periods

step_by_step.title: Apply the Formula
step_by_step.description: Divide FV by (1 + r) raised to the power of n

practiceProblems.question: You will receive $10,000 in 5 years. If the discount rate is 8%, what is the present value?

solution.explanation: The present value of $10,000 received in 5 years at 8% discount rate is $6,806. This means you should be indifferent between receiving $6,806 today or $10,000 in 5 years.

content.text: Future Value (FV) shows how much today's money will be worth at a future date, assuming a specific rate of return.

compoundingConcept.title: The Power of Compounding
compoundingConcept.description: Compounding occurs when you earn returns not just on your initial investment, but also on the returns from previous periods. Einstein allegedly called it 'the eighth wonder of the world.'

visualization.note: Notice how the interest earned grows each year because you're earning interest on interest!

practiceProblems.question: If you invest $5,000 today at 12% annual interest, compounded annually, how much will you have in 10 years?

solution.explanation: Your $5,000 investment will grow to $15,529 in 10 years, representing a gain of $10,529 due to compound interest.

content.text: The discount rate is the interest rate used to determine the present value of future cash flows. Choosing the right discount rate is crucial for accurate valuation.

factors.name: Risk-Free Rate
factors.description: The return on a risk-free investment, typically U.S. Treasury bonds

factors.name: Risk Premium
factors.description: Additional return required to compensate for risk
factors.example: Corporate bonds might require 2-3% above Treasury rates

factors.name: Inflation Expectations
factors.description: Expected rate of price increases over time

factors.name: Opportunity Cost
factors.description: Return you could earn on alternative investments of similar risk
factors.example: If you could earn 8% elsewhere, use 8% as discount rate

content.text: Time value of money principles appear everywhere in finance and life. Here are key applications:

scenarios.title: Retirement Planning
scenarios.problem: How much do I need to save monthly to have $1 million at retirement?
scenarios.approach: Use present value of annuity formulas to determine required monthly contributions
scenarios.example: To accumulate $1M in 30 years at 8% return, you need to save approximately $670 per month

scenarios.title: Loan Payments
scenarios.problem: What will my monthly mortgage payment be?
scenarios.approach: The loan amount is the present value of all future payments
scenarios.example: $400,000 loan at 6% for 30 years = $2,398 monthly payment

scenarios.title: Investment Decisions
scenarios.problem: Should I invest in Project A or Project B?
scenarios.approach: Calculate net present value (NPV) of each project's cash flows
scenarios.example: Choose the project with higher positive NPV

scenarios.title: Stock Valuation
scenarios.approach: Present value of expected future dividends and capital gains
scenarios.example: Dividend discount model uses TVM to value stocks

content.text: Even experienced professionals make these TVM errors. Learn to spot and avoid them:

mistakes.description: Using nominal interest rates with real cash flows or vice versa
mistakes.solution: Always match: nominal rates with nominal cash flows, real rates with real cash flows

mistakes.description: Assuming annual compounding when it's monthly or daily
mistakes.solution: Adjust both the rate and number of periods for compounding frequency

mistakes.description: Not accounting for when cash flows actually occur
mistakes.solution: Map out exact timing of all cash flows on a timeline

mistakes.description: Applying the same rate to all cash flows regardless of risk
mistakes.solution: Match discount rates to the riskiness of each cash flow

questions.question: Which statement best explains why a dollar today is worth more than a dollar in the future?
options: Money can be invested to earn returns
questions.explanation: While inflation and uncertainty play roles, the primary reason is that money can be invested to earn returns, creating opportunity cost for waiting.
